newsitem.title: GHANA: Ghana's Rawlings inches towards election victory.
newsitem.headline: Ghana's Rawlings inches towards election victory.

text.p: Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings inched towards victory on Wednesday in a slow-motion election count after Saturday's presidential and parliamentary poll.
Edward Mahama, who has been lying a distant third behind Rawlings and second-placed John Kufuor, threw in the towel as the president's victory looked like a foregone conclusion.

"I want to avail myself of this opportunity...to concede that I am out of the race and to congratratulate Flight-Lieutenant J. J. Rawlings for his victory," Mahama of the People's National Convention said in a statement.
With results in from 179 of the 200 constituencies, Rawlings enjoyed a comfortable lead with 56 percent of votes.
His main rival, Kufuor of the opposition's Great Alliance, had 41 percent, according to the results from the National Election Commission. Mahama had less than three percent.
In the parliamentary ballot, the president's National Democratic Congress party had 117 seats in the 200-seat assembly. The combined opposition had 62 seats.
No incumbent has been re-elected since Ghana, which has a history of coups, won independence from Britain in 1957.
A landslide win in the parliamentary election would further strengthen the hand of Rawlings, who has dominated the West African nation's political scene for almost two decades.
Anxiety was running high in the capital Accra about the delayed announcement of the final result, which were originally expected on Monday or Tuesday.
Even Rawlings complained in a speech on Tuesday, saying the prolonged delay was unfortunate.
Proclamation of final results was expected late on Wednesday because of the need to double-check some returns from the interior, Election Commission chairman Kwadwo Afari-Gyan said.
Rawlings, 49, a charismatic former air force pilot, twice seized power in the West African nation. He ruled unchallenged for 15 years before first winning a popular mandate in 1992.
The election commission put turnout at about 80 percent.

Commonwealth and Organisation of African Unity observers have paid tribute to the conduct and fairness of the elections. "This is by far the best organised election I have seen in West Africa," one Western monitor said.
